description:
Eragrostis curvula, commonly known as weeping lovegrass, is a perennial grass species native to southern Africa. It belongs to the family Poaceae, which is the largest family of flowering plants.

Eragrostis curvula is a tufted, warm-season grass that can grow up to 1.5 meters tall. The leaves are narrow, linear, and can reach up to 30 cm in length. The inflorescence is a panicle, which is a type of branched flower cluster, and can be up to 30 cm long. The spikelets, the basic unit of the grass inflorescence, are small, containing two to eight florets.

The species is well-adapted to a wide range of environmental conditions, including drought, poor soil fertility, and high temperatures. It is commonly used for erosion control, as a forage crop, and in landscaping and revegetation projects. Eragrostis curvula is considered an important grass species in its native range and has been introduced to other parts of the world, including the United States, Australia, and South America.
